headline: Russian-Ukraine war: Why African countries did not interfere
summarized_story:

“There’s a strong strand of thought in African diplomacy that says African states should maintain the principle of non-interference and so they shouldn’t get caught up in proxy wars between the East and the West.

headline: How corruption denies Nigeria of mining sector dollars
summarized_story:
The Nigerian government is losing billions of dollars to illegal mining activities in the country’s solid minerals sector as corruption continues to hold sway.
Last year, market researchers at CSL Stockbrokers warned that illegal mining activities had continued to wipe gains in the sector.
Across the country, large-scale illegal mining and small-scale artisanal mining dot the nation’s landscape.
In theory, it is not possible to engage in mining activities without a mining permit.
They are paid huge amounts of money by the mining companies to support their activities and they do not report these illegal mining activities to the authorities.

headline: Botswana, Ghana, South Africa show what Nigeria is missing
summarized_story:
Some other African countries such as Botswana, Ghana and South Africa have been able to push ahead with the development of their mineral resources since then, leaving Nigeria behind.
The country’s gold mining sector is one of the oldest in Africa, and retains a crucial role in the Ghanaian economy.
Since the discovery of diamonds in 1867 and subsequently of gold, the mineral sector has contributed to making South Africa the most advanced economy in Africa.
Data from Statista show that in 2019, the mining sector in South Africa contributed with an added value of approximately 226.2 billion South African Rand (roughly $13.5 billion) to the country’s GDP.
As of 2021, the distribution of the market capitalisation of mineral commodities in South Africa, by mineral, showed that platinum accounted for a 65 percent share of the market capitalisation of mineral commodities in South Africa.

headline: The Big scam: Fresh doubts over NNPC’s 75 million per day consumption figures

summarized_story:

headline: Amid Rising Prices, CBN Retains Benchmark Interest Rate At 11.5%
summarized_story:
﻿Amid inflationary pressures sparked in part by the Russia-Ukraine war, the Central Bank of Nigeria’s Monetary Policy Committee has retained the Monetary Policy Rate (MPR) at 11.5% and kept all other parameters unchanged.
CBN Governor Godwin Emefiele made the announcement while addressing journalists on Monday.
The MPR, which has remained unchanged for months, is a tool for regulating interest rates in the economy.
Lowering the rate could have stimulated more borrowing while raising the rate could have signaled the CBN’s intention to reduce the economy’s money supply.
“In the case of whether to loosen, the committee feels that loosening will trigger further liquidity surfeit and fuel inflationary pressure as available funds outstrips the economy’s absorptive capacity or domestic capacity utilisation.

headline: Court Strikes Out Suit Seeking To Halt Umahi’s Removal From Office
summarized_story:
A Federal High Court in Abuja has struck out a motion on notice filed by Ebonyi State Governor, David Umahi, seeking to stay the execution of a judgment removing him from office.
Justice Inyang Ekwo struck out the motion on Monday following the withdrawal of the case by the plaintiffs in the suit.
A Senior Advocate of Nigeria (SAN), Chukwuma Ma-Chukwu Ume, who represented Governor Umahi and his deputy, Kelechi Igwe, informed the court of the new development.
But in the motion on notice dated March 9, Umahi and Igwe prayed the court for an order staying the execution of its orders made the previous day.
They had also asked the court to stay the execution of its order directing INEC to hold a governorship election, in accordance with Section 177(C) of the 1999 Constitution.

headline: Plane Carrying 133 Crashes Into Mountains In China
